title: Ultimate Chicago Fall Brunch Guide
text:
Ultimate Chicago Fall Brunch Guide Where To Hunker Down When The Weather Turns Colder Sign Up for our Free Newsletters Thanks, You're in! Health Tip of the Day Sign up There was an error. Please try again. Please select a newsletter. Please enter a valid email address. Did you mean ? Updated Articles and Resources mEAT's wild salmon hash for brunch. Photo courtesy of mEAT 
Chicago's brunch scene shows no signs of slowing down--and that's a good thing. It's so diverse and vast that you could literally dine at two different places every day of the year. But since that's way too ambitious--and obsessive--we've narrowed down the choices with a list showcasing only the very best Windy City offerings. 
From appropriate family-friendly finds to flawless chef-driven destinations certain to make your Chicago trip memorable, our selections cover all the bases. 
BOOZY 
Bistronomic . The French-focused eatery features the classic Croque Monsieur , plus short-stack pancakes, French toast, omelets and pork belly Benedict. For an extra $15, guests may indulge in bottomless mimosas for two hours . Brunch is served 10 a.m.-2:30 p.m. Saturday and Sunday. 840 N. Wabash Ave., 312-944-8400 
Brasserie by LM . At this French-inspired restaurant, it'll cost you $25 for bottomless mimosas, plus an entree. Choose from the likes of steel-cut oats topped with fresh berries, a brasserie burger and savory crepes. Brunch is served 11 a.m.-2 p.m. Saturday and Sunday. 800 S. Michigan Ave., 312-431-1788 
Bull & Bear . The trendy neighborhood sports lounge offers dishes such as crab cake Benedict, Bananas Foster French toast, homemade "Pop Tarts" and breakfast tacos. For an extra $20, guests may get bottomless mimosas and Bloody Mary cocktails. Brunch is served 10 a.m.-4 p.m. Saturday and Sunday. 431 N. Wells St., 312-527-5973 
Chicago Q . One of our favorite BBQ restaurants in Chicago serves brunch every weekend. You'll find some of the signature BBQ items (smoked chicken or Kobe brisket eggs Benedict) on the menu as well as tuned-up brunch dishes such as cheddar chive biscuits and gravy as well as carrot cake pancakes. Twenty bucks gets you bottomless mimosas. Brunch occurs 11 a.m.-3 p.m. Saturday, Sunday. 1160 N. Wabash Ave., 312-642-1160 
Crocodile . Twenty-five dollars gets you an unlimited buffet of booze and brunch. The menu occasionally switches up, but expect standards like spicy scrambled eggs, cheesy grits, BBQ ribs, apple cinnamon French toast, a roast beef carving station and more. The deal includes unlimited mimosas and Bloody Mary cocktails. 11 a.m.-4 p.m. Saturday, Sunday. 1540 N. Milwaukee Ave., 773-252-0880 
Parson's Chicken & Fish . There are only four entrees on the brunch menu, including chicken biscuit and buttermilk pancakes, but we have a feeling that most folks are coming for the cocktail offerings. At the top of the list is a "5 Spice Bellini," but there is certainly nothing shabby about the "Green Maria" (made with tomatillos) or classic Irish Coffee. Brunch is served daily 10 a.m.-3:30 p.m. daily. 2952 W. Armitage Ave., 773-384-3333 
Pump Room at Public Hotel Chicago . Make the occasion celebratory by ordering "brunch bubbles" tableside. It's a bottle of prosecco served with freshly squeezed orange juice and an assortment of craft syrups (passion fruit chili, raspberry lychee, blood orange). All dishes are a la carte, such as whole-wheat flatbreads, chicken sandwich with spicy mayo, and Belgian waffles with whipped cream. Brunch is 9 a.m.-3 p.m. Saturday, Sunday. 1301 N. State Pkwy., 312-229-6740 
BUDGET 
3rd Coast Cafe . The cozy, art gallery-like institution is nestled deep in the Gold Coast and is a neighborhood favorite,especially for its fireplace. Specialty brunch dishes include veggie hash, chilaquiles, Mexican steak and eggs, and a Norwegian lox & bagel plate that comes with cucumber. All items are under $14. Brunch is served 7 a.m.-3 p.m. Saturday, Sunday. 1260 N. Dearborn St., 312-649-0730 
Batter & Berries . From a flight of French toast (a sampler of blueberry, lemon, caramel and strawberry) to chicken-stuffed sweet potato waffles, this quaint Lakeview spot is from a husband-and-wife team. Brunch entrees do not exceed $14. Brunch is served 8 a.m.-3 p.m. Saturday, Sunday. 2748 N. Lincoln Ave., 773-248-7710 
Bijan's Bistro . The restaurant is one of the few serving daily brunch (10 a.m.-4 p.m.). That's great because who doesn't have a taste for griddled pancakes, omelets or a fried egg BLT at 3 p.m.? Prices range $6-$13. 663 N. State St., 312-202-1904 
Nookies . Hungry for brunch all day ? The Old Town location serves up all your morning faves, plus it's BYOB. Dig into inexpensive best sellers like the strawberry Belgian waffles, crunchy French toast and a chili-avocado frittata. All items are under $14. 1746 N. Wells St., 312-337-2454 
Tempo Cafe . This classic American diner serves up inexpensive breakfast fare 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. It's a favorite for families during the day and after-hours crowds late night for heaving portions of omelets, fruit-topped pancakes and waffles. All items are under $14. 6 E. Chestnut St., 312-943-4373 
West Egg Cafe . The egg-centric restaurant specializes in signature omelets (made with ingredients such as chorizo, green chiles, corned beef or broccoli), gourmet waffles and French toast. Brunch occurs 7 a.m.-3 p.m. Saturday and Sunday. 620 N. Fairmont Ct., 312-280-8366 
Yolk . What started off as an unassuming little breakfast nook in the South Loop now draws long lines at newer locations in River North (747 N. Wells St., 312-787-2277) , Streeterville (355 E. Ohio St., 312-822-9655) and the West Loop (500 W. Madison St., 312-454-9655). Yolk specializes in superior egg dishes--particularly its fluffy frittatas --but also look out for some tasty crepes, waffles and burgers. The bright and cheery room gets thumbs up from the stroller set, and the staff knows how to keep kids happy. Brunch takes place 7 a.m.-3 p.m. Saturday and Sunday. 1120 S. Michigan Ave., 312-789-9655 
BUFFET 
House of Blues . The music hall is the setting for the weekly Gospel Brunch, which spotlights well-known gospel singers such as Kirk Franklin. The buffet-style event offers Southern cuisine favorites like fried chicken, mashed potatoes, peel-and-eat shrimp and turnip greens. It's $40 for adults, $25 for children and free for children under six.Brunch occurs 10 a.m.-2 p.m. Sunday. 329 N. Dearborn St., 312-923-2000 
Shaw's Crab House . Fifty-five dollars per person (children under 12 dine free) gets you a sweet selection at one of Chicago's most highly regarded seafood restaurants . The grand buffet includes a cold seafood bar, surf & turf station (with roast beef tenderloin, lobster bisque, king crab legs), omelet and waffle kitchen and dessert table. The price includes fresh brewed coffee, juice, tea and soda. Brunch is 11:30 a.m.-1:30 p.m. Sunday. 21 E. Hubbard St., 312-527-2722 
Signature Room . Plan a leisurely day that begins with a trip to the John Hancock Observatory and ends with brunch in the Signature Room--with unobstructed views of the city. Assorted charcuterie, gourmet soups, chilled seafood and desserts make up the buffet; diners may also choose from made-to-order entrees such as brioche French toast, brie and pear quiche, steak and eggs, and chicken piccata. It's $45 for adults; $25 for children under 12. 875 N. Michigan Ave., 312-787-9596 
Sinha Elegant Cuisine . Directly across the street from the United Center is this authentic South American find where a Brazilian-born woman generously opens her home for public consumption. Sunday brunch (two seatings at 2 and 4 p.m.) includes live entertainment, samba dancing and an all-you-can-eat spread of classic Brazilian dishes such as basmati rice, black beans and fish stew. It's $30 per person and BYOB. 2018 W. Adams St., 312-491-8200 
Stanley's Kitchen & Tap . For $13.95, guests may chow down on as many Southern-inspired dishes as possible. Highlights of the brunch menu include fried chicken, mashed potatoes, cheddar cheesy grits, buttermilk biscuits and gravy, bourbon glazed ham and more. There are also freshly squeezed mimosas and a build-your-own Bloody Mary bar. Brunch is 10 a.m.-4 p.m. Saturday, Sunday. 1970 N. Lincoln Ave., 312-642-0007 
CHEF DRIVEN 
2 Sparrows . Seasonal punches, made with fresh, seasonal ingredients, change every few months to complement dishes such as biscuits with lamb sausage gravy, fruit-infused pancakes and house-made doughnuts and "pop tarts."9 a.m.-2 p.m. Saturday, Sunday brunch. 553 W. Diversey Pkwy., 773-234-2320 
Acadia . You'll have your choice of many egg dishes as chef/owner Ryan McCaskey is obsessed with them. From a scotch egg with violet mustard to a lobster eggs Benedict with truffle lobster hollandaise, Serrano ham and country potatoes, you cannot go wrong. Just make sure you start with the pastries, which are complimentary . Brunch is 11 a.m.-2 p.m. Sunday. 1639 S. Wabash Ave., 312-360-9500 
Au Cheval . This trendy West Loop spot deserves to be on our best brunch list as much as it's one of our favorite burgers . You can get the cheeseburger as well as crispy potato hash with duck heart gravy or foie gras with scrambled eggs. 11 a.m.-3 p.m. Saturday; 10 a.m.-3 p.m. Sunday. 800 W. Randolph St., 312-929-4580 
Avec . Highlights on this unique menu include wood-oven baked French toast, Moroccan pancakes with fried chicken wings, and breakfast paella with chicken confit, snail boudin, eggs and tangerine aioli. 10 a.m.-2 p.m. Sunday. 615 W. Randolph St., 312-377-2002 
Bistro Campagne . The long-time French bistro embraces a farm-to-table approach. It's a Lincoln Square favorite, mostly because of the seasonal ingredients enhancing classic fare like crepes Suzettes, duck confit over hash, and brioche French toast. Brunch is 11 a.m. -2 p.m. every Sunday. 4518 N. Lincoln Ave., 773-271-6100 
Carriage House . Classic Southern dishes are taken to the next level: chicken and biscuits dripping in sausage gravy; a garlic bologna sandwich on a brioche bun and topped with a fried egg; and crispy pork belly with grits and eggs. Brunch occurs 10 a.m.-2 p.m. Friday through Sunday. 1700 W. Division St., 773-384-9700 
Davanti Enoteca . Start at the build-your-own Bloody Mary bar, where you'll get to choose from literally more than 100 ingredients, toppings and hot sauces. The menu is Italian focused with house-made delights such as lemon-ricotta pancakes, biscuits topped with prosciutto gravy, and steel-cut oats with brown sugar and banana. Brunch takes place 10:30 a.m.-3 p.m. Saturday, Sunday. 30 E. Hubbard St., 312-605-5900 
Farmhouse . The menu at the farm-to-table concept extends to brunch service when such comfort food dishes as farm egg scramble, short rib hash and BBQ pork sandwich are served. Guests may also choose from three different mimosas, including one made from sparkling rose . 10 a.m.-3 p.m. Saturday, Sunday. 228 W. Chicago Ave., 312-280-4960 
Fat Rice . The Macanese dim sum menu includes items like steamed "ten karat" shrimp dumplings, Portuguese egg tarts, and Macanese minchi made with stir-fried minced pork, beef and lamb, a fried egg, coconut rice and potato crouton. 11 a.m.-2 p.m. Friday, Saturday; 11 a.m.-3 p.m. Sunday. 2957 W. Diversey Ave., 773-661-9170 
GT Fish & Oyster . The globally influenced menu consists of house-made churros, brioche French toast with bananas, Nutella and hazelnuts, a smoked whitefish quiche, and biscuits and lobster gravy. A dedicated brunch cocktail menu offers more selections than you'll find at most spots. 10 a.m.-2:30 p.m. Saturday, Sunday. 531 N. Wells St., 312-929-3501 
La Sirena Clandestina . The Argentinean-inspired brunch offers items such as rabanada (fried French toast, dulce de leche, bananas, cachaca), breakfast empanada (bacon, sage and cheddar) and feijoada fries (black beans, provolone, pickled fresnos, green onions, sour cream and mustard sauce, fried egg). 10 a.m.-3 p.m. Sunday. 954 W. Fulton Market, 312-226-5300 
Longman & Eagle . Brunch is homey with hearty, shareable dishes like fried chicken and waffles with sweet potato and pork belly hash; kid-friendly cinnamon-spiced brioche French toast with praline pecans; and house-made biscuits smothered in pork sausage gravy. Diners will also find an entrée on this menu that's meant to appeal to its hipster heavy neighborhood: the PBR Breakfast of two eggs, bacon or house-made sausage, house potatoes and an ice-cold can of PBR. 9 a.m.-2 p.m. Saturday and Sunday. 2657 N. Kedzie Ave., 773-276-7110 
Lula Cafe . One of the pioneers in the local and sustainable scene, Lula's brunch menu is forever changing. What's great is that it's not so out there that you won't recognize the dishes. Start with something simple such as a half white grapefruit with candied seeds and move on to savory delights such as an almond crepe or three-grain risotto. 2537 N. Kedzie Ave., 773-489-9554 
Max's Wine Dive . The crispy fried chicken and champagne get diners in the door, but there's so much more to offer on the brunch menu. There's braised short rib with egg hash, creamy shrimp 'n' grits, and blueberry pancakes. Of course, you shouldn't allow that to stop you from consuming as much bubbly as possible.Brunch is 10 a.m.-3 p.m. Friday through Sunday. 1482 N. Milwaukee Ave., 773-661-6581 
Nico Osteria . The Thompson Chicago 's red-hot dining-and-drinking destination is more laid back during brunch and that's a good thing if you're looking for something chill. The Italian-focused menu is quite unconventional for the Gold Coast with dishes such as porcini-rubbed hanger steak and soft-scrambled eggs with peperonata, prosciutto and olive focaccia. 9 a.m.-2:30 p.m. Saturday, Sunday. 1015 N. Rush St., 312-994-7100 
Old Town Social . A great spot to catch sports action of any sort, OTS also serves a very good chef-driven brunch to complement the action. Dig into generous portions of turkey pastrami hash, grilled sausage & waffles, Bananas Foster French toast and piping-hot beignets. Brunch is served 11 a.m.-3 p.m. Saturday, Sunday . 455 W. North Ave., 312-266-2277 
The Publican . The brainchild of Michelin-starred chef Paul Kahan , Publican cranks out unconventional bites to the delight of its many fans. Brunch is seasonal and consistent with a few savory standbys: red wine poached eggs with prosciutto and sourdough; maple syrup-braised bacon; pork schnitzel with waffles; and the signature Publican "mimosa" of Belgian beer and freshly squeezed OJ. 10 a.m.-2 p.m. Saturday and Sunday. 837 W. Fulton Market, 312-733-9555 
Promontory . Owned by the same team behind Longman & Eagle, this popular Hyde Park restaurant and live music venue offers brunch 9 a.m.-3 p.m. Saturday and Sunday. A few of the highlights include potato gnocchi lobster hash, French toast topped with peach bread pudding and grilled skirt steak paired with a red wine poached egg. 5311 S. Lake Park Ave West, 312-801-2100 
FAMILY 
Ann Sather . You'll find three-egg omelets, waffles and pancakes on the menu, but no meal is complete without ordering a round of the famous sticky, gooey home-made cinnamon rolls.9 a.m.-2 p.m. Saturday, Sunday. 909 W. Belmont Ave., 773-348-2378 
Bongo Room . The original Wicker Park location still draws fans willing to wait outside patiently for their turn to chow down on signature dishes such as the Chocolate Tower French Toast, BLT Benedict and sweet potato and black bean burrito.9 a.m.-2 p.m. Saturday, Sunday. 1470 N. Milwaukee Ave., 773-489-0690 
Feast . Fun, kid-friendly dishes include oatmeal pancakes with honey-vanilla butter, Margherita pizza and the option to build-your-own omelet. 9 a.m.-2 p.m. Saturday, Sunday. 1616 N. Damen Ave., 773-772-7100 
Hash House a Go Go . What kid doesn't like the idea of pancakes as big as their heads? Brunch and breakfast items are served all day at this quirky spot that also features a number of hashes served with fruit and biscuits, egg scrambles and one-pound burgers. 1212 N. State Pkwy., 312-202-0994 
Mindy's Hot Chocolate . You'll find way more than hot chocolate on the menu at one of Bucktown's favorites. The mac 'n' cheese never changes on the seasonal menu, plus you're likely to find variations of the smoked chicken salad, buttermilk pancakes and brunch fried rice. Brunch occurs 10 a.m.-2 p.m . Saturday, Sunday. 1747 N. Damen Ave., 773-489-1747 
Kitsch'n on Roscoe . Here's another popular spot serving brunch daily, and it gives visitors an opportunity to explore the quaint little neighborhood of Roscoe Village. Enjoy throwback dishes like Green Eggs & Ham (can be modified for vegetarians), a candied bacon brunch BLT and cinnamon toast. Brunch occurs daily 8:30 a.m.-3 p.m. 2005 W. Roscoe St., 773-248-7372 
Little Goat . Stephanie Izard ’s contemporary West Loop diner’s open all day, and most kids will be thrilled that they can order breakfast at any time. The dark chocolate chip crunch pancakes with chocolate malt butter, Fat Elvis waffles with bananas, peanut butter and bacon maple syrup or gooey, house-made Cinnabuns should put them on happy street. 820 W. Randolph St., 312-888-3455 
Wishbone . Another Deep South-focused brunch--which was a favorite of Oprah Winfrey 's when she lived in Chicago--remains a popular option in the West Loop. Top sellers include some of the regional choices like the Savannah shrimp omelet (shrimp, ham, grilled onion, peppers, cheddar & cilantro salsa), Kentucky scrambled eggs (eggs scrambled with corn and peppers) and North Carolina-style crab cakes prepared with lemon-butter sauce. Brunch is served 8 a.m.-3 p.m. Saturday, Sunday. 1001 W. Washington Blvd., 312-850-2663 
FANCY 
Allium . The Four Seasons ' lobby-level restaurant goes contemporary with its $58 per person offering. Guests share small plates (oyster shooters, charcuterie, chilled jumbo shrimp, bison sloppy Joes, etc.) from a towering display, then choose an entrée such as steak & eggs, Nutella hot cakes or a savory French toast. A signature brunch cocktail (or beer or mimosa) is included in the price as well as a dessert buffet where you can make your own ice cream sandwich. Brunch is served 11 a.m.-3 p.m. Sunday. 120 E. Delaware St., 312-799-4900 
Deca . Prices range $22-$27 for entrees at the Ritz-Carlton Chicago 'slobby restaurant. Though you don't have to dress up, the vibe is white tablecloths and somewhat hushed voices. You'll find a fresh seafood and shellfish tower, roasted half chicken and steak frites on the menu. Brunch happens 10:30 a.m.-5 p.m. Sunday. 160 E. Pearson St., 312-312-573-5160 
Fred's at Barney's New York. Do some damage in the luxury retail store, then head up to the posh eatery for a prix-fixe brunch for $32 per person. You'll get a beverage (Bloody Mary, mimosa or soda), plus house salad and entree (such as New York-style pastrami hash, brioche French toast) served with sausage and breakfast potatoes. Brunch occurs 11 a.m.-3 p.m. Saturday, Sunday. 15 E. Oak St., 312-596-1111 
NoMi . You can, of course, order pancakes or waffles at the Park Hyatt ' s award-winning eatery, but have a little fun and indulge in something a little different like a smoked salmon tartine or roasted vegetable panini. There is also sushi on the menu. Brunch is featured 11:30 a.m.-2 p.m. Saturday, Sunday. 800 N. Michigan Ave., 312 -239-4030 
North Pond . Nothing beats brunch over a great view, and this James Beard-winning restaurant offers that and plenty more. For $34 per person, guests choose seasonal dishes for a three-course meal. A nice stroll over to the nearby Lincoln Park Zoo caps off a perfect afternoon. Brunch is 10:30 a.m.-1:30 p.m. Sunday. 2610 N. Cannon Dr., 773-477-5845 
Perennial Virant . Located directly across the street from Green City Market, Perennial Virant takes advantage of its prime location by incorporating farm-fresh and local ingredients into all its seasonal dishes. That means, of course, brunch is never the same (that's a good thing!) and the morning cocktails follow the same rule of thumb with ever-changing ingredients in the signature bloody Mary and mimosa. Brunch takes place 10 a.m.-2 p.m. Saturday and Sunday. 1800 N. Lincoln Ave., 312-981-7070 
RL . A favorite of socialites and visiting celebrities, the Italian steakhouse is also a popular brunch hang. Classic RL dishes include corned beef hash, cinnamon-vanilla French toast and a lobster club topped with bacon and truffle mayonnaise. Brunch is served 10 a.m.-5 p.m. Sunday. 115 E. Chicago Ave., 312-475-1100 
UNCONVENTIONAL 
The Bristol . The ultimate hangover brunch spot for foodies actually features a regular entree called the "hangover breakfast" of noodles, pork broth, shrimp mousse and pork belly. Not into the swine? The smoked gouda burger should do the trick, as it's also topped with duck confit, cherry peppers, grilled vidalias and dijonnaise. Brunch occurs 10 a.m.-2 p.m. Saturday, Sunday. 2152 N. Damen Ave., 773-862-5555 
Carnivale . Live Latin beats provide an appropriate soundtrack to a festive menu with such stars as coconut shrimp, churrasco, churro-style waffles topped with sugar, cinnamon and Mexican chocolate ganache, and a Spanish Benedict. Brunch commences 10:30 a.m.-3 p.m. Sunday. 702 W. Fulton St., 312-850-5005 
The Gage . During the week, The Gage bustles with business executives and after-work crowds, but weekends are reserved for chilling out. That's when the restaurant specializes in a mostly Irish breakfast with updated spins on traditional dishes like a Scotch egg, corned beef hash, bangers and black pudding. The restaurant is directly across the street from Millennium Park . Brunch hours are 10 a.m.-2 p.m. Saturday and Sunday. 24 S. Michigan Ave., 312-372-4243 
JAM . Almost every Chicago restaurant offers French toast of some sort, but JAM revolutionized the classic brunch dish. Every day you will find malted custard French toast on the menu, which is one of the items that put the Logan Square sensation on the map. Brunch is served every day 7 a.m.-3 p.m. 3057 W. Logan Blvd., 773-292-6011 
Jellyfish . One of our top sushi spots around town now serves brunch. A number of offbeat dishes and drinks are on the menu, but you'll want the fruit "sushi" all to yourself. Coconut rice is rolled and stuffed with strawberry, banana, pineapple and mango, and topped with strawberry and mango puree, plus shaved white and dark chocolate.Brunch is 11 a.m.-2 p.m. Saturday and Sunday. 1009 N. Rush St., 312-660-3111 
Kit Kat Lounge & Supper Club . You won't find any other place in town where you'll encounter a brunch like this: men performing in full drag as every diva ranging from Diana Ross to Lady Gaga . Enjoy the show while noshing on items like bacon truffle mac 'n' cheese, Rice Krispie French toast or a "Big Hot Mess" of fried chicken and biscuits accompanied by two eggs served sunny side up. Brunch is 11 a.m.-3 p.m. Sunday. 3700 N. Halsted St., 773-525-1111 
mEAT . The Boystown sensation has opened a Near North outpost and this one does brunch. It's unconventional in the sense that you're encouraged to start with the breakfast fondue. It's cheese and honey and accompanied by fresh fruit, grilled sausage, house-made breads, waffles, bagel bites and more. You can order so much more, including a number of skewers like cinnamon-glazed bacon, beef tenderloin tips and rosemary mint pork. Side dishes are big enough to share--or have as an entree--such as Belgian waffles with grilled pineapple as well as wild salmon hash. 10 a.m.-3 p.m. Saturday, Sunday. 215 E. Chestnut St., 773-328-8320 
Three Aces . The hard rockin' biker bar/restaurant is yet another spot serving brunch every day (11 a.m.-4 p.m.). In addition to serving such popular bites as breakfast poutine (fries, sausage gravy, fried egg, bacon, bacon siracha, scallions), suckling skillet (suckling pig, escarole, potatoes, fried egg, cheddar, calabrian chiles, smoked poblano hot sauce) and a black kale salad (roasted beet, orange supremes, goat cheese, honey pecans), the Little Italy destination attracts authentic bikers for special brunches during warmer months. 1321 W. Taylor St., 312-243-1577 
Whisk . The Ukrainian Village BYO has quickly gained fans from the neighborhood and beyond for its daily brunch from 7 a.m. to 5 p.m. What's on the menu? New takes on classic Southern American and Mexican fare, from egg scrambles and salted caramel pancakes to a chorizo omelet filled with queso fresco and avocado.There are also a host of craft bottled sodas such as butterscotch rootbeer. 2018 W. Chicago Ave., 773-252-9060 Related Articles
